docs.lead_paragraph: A New Jersey State judge yesterday froze about $5 million in assets of a doctor who heads a troubled health maintenance organization and ordered him to post a bond of $840,000 while regulators review the company's financial records, officials said. Judge Anthony J. Parrillo of Superior Court also ordered the doctor, Magdy Elamir, who is president of American Preferred Provider Plan, to give a full accounting of his personal assets and liabilities to the State Department of Banking and Insurance within 20 days, said Emerald Kuepper, a deputy State Attorney General.

headline.main: Metro Business; Judge Freezes Assets Of Head of H.M.O.

docs.abstract: New Jersey Superior Court Judge Anthony J Parrillo freezes $5 million in assets of Dr Magdy Elamir, who heads American Preferred Provider Plan, troubled health maintenance organization; judge orders him to post bond of $840,000 while regulators review company's financial records; at issue are transactions in which Elamir directed millions of dollars from HMO's accounts to subsidiaries he also controls (S)
docs.snippet: A New Jersey State judge yesterday froze about $5 million in assets of a doctor who heads a troubled health maintenance organization and ordered him to post a bond of $840,000 while regulators review the company's financial records, officials said.  ...

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: AETNA INC.'s proposed purchase of the health care business of the Prudential Insurance Company of America has touched off concern among doctors and consumers, but Aetna's large size could ultimately benefit patients. The acquisition would create the nation's largest health insurer, serving 1 in every 10 Americans and writing contracts with at least half of the nation's physicians. Doctors fear the behemoth will harden Aetna's already aggressive assault on tests and procedures it deems excessive, and some consumer advocates worry that an enlarged Aetna will bully patients. Rival insurance companies recoil at the prospect of competing against a company with the market power to negotiate steep discounts with hospitals.

headline.main: Economic Scene; In the health care business, size can ultimately benefit patients.

docs.abstract: Economic Scene column on Aetna Inc's proposed purchase of health care business of Prudential Insurance Co of America; says merger has touched off concern among doctors and consumers, but Aetna's large size could ultimately benefit patients (M)

keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: Complaints upheld against health maintenance organizations in New York more than doubled in 1997, state insurance officials reported yesterday. The annual complaint ranking by the State Department of Insurance found that the five largest H.M.O.'s in New York accounted for more than three quarters of all H.M.O.-related complaints from consumers and doctors upheld by state regulators that year.

headline.main: Metro Business; H.M.O.'s Are Losing More State Appeals

docs.abstract: State Insurance Dept says complaints upheld against health maintenance organizations in New York more than doubled in 1997; says HMO's accounted for 1,400 of 2,250 upheld complaints brought against health insurers (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day last Friday about the plans of Aetna Inc. to buy Prudential Health Care misidentified one of the three largest nationwide health insurance companies. Along with Aetna and the United Healthcare Corporation, the company is Cigna, not Kaiser Permanente. A chart with the article misidentified the chief executive of Prudential Health Care. He is Steven J. Shulman; Arthur F. Ryan is chief executive of Prudential Health Care's parent, the Prudential Insurance Company of America.
docs.abstract: Correction of December 11 Business Day article on plans by Aetna Inc to acquire Prudential Health Care

docs.lead_paragraph: Q. Should physicians accept presents from their patients? ALISHA BERGER Most physicians are delighted by the gifts their patients give them. They are gracious tokens of affection and gratitude. But theoretically, gifts from patients may cause ethical problems by creating a sense of obligation and hence potential conflicts of interest. For example, what if a doctor accepts gifts as ''payment'' for extra time and attention in this age of managed care?

headline.main: Gifts From Patients Create a Quandary

docs.abstract: Pro and Con column on question of whether physicians should accept gifts from their patients; drawing (S)
